item.title: Help affected families from COVID-19
item.description:
The “Ariel” project was created by the Jewish Community of Estonia during the 2008 crisis to help people who have experienced a difficult economic situation, mainly who have lost their jobs. In April 2020, in connection with the crisis situation as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, the “Ariel” anti-crisis center resumed its work. The economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic has affected many members of the Community. Within the framework of the “Ariel” project, information is collected and published through the community’s media channels, which helps to navigate the various components of life in crisis and after it. We help those who have lost their jobs or whose financial capabilities have changed significantly. Over the time that has passed since the resumption of the work of the anti-crisis center, more than 55 households have already contacted us and received support.

item.title: Help Jewish Community of Estonia
item.description:
The Forum of Estonian Jewry “Yahad” has long become the hallmark of the Jewish community in Estonia. On the days of the event, participants are given the opportunity to learn about the history of the community, as well as about its activities today. The rich program provides an opportunity for an interesting, but sometimes not easy choice: each of the participants can choose one of the events taking place in parallel in different audiences. Topics vary: Judaism, Jewish traditions, the cycle of Jewish life, culture, history, education, literature, psychology, politics, cooking, sports and much more. More than 50 events in the form of lectures, concerts, creative meetings, including film screenings of Jewish and Israeli authors, Jewish dances, excursions, discussions. We call for financial support for this distinctive phenomenon and the organizers of this annual event.

item.title: Help pensioners
item.description:
The Social Center of the Jewish Community of Estonia extends a helping hand to the most vulnerable layers of the country’s Jewish population - pensioners, disabled people, single-parent families and needy children - so that they can live with dignity in the difficult conditions of the modern world. We also care about preserving Jewish values. In order for our wards to feel surrounded by care, it is very important for them that the support coming from the Jewish community is constant. We call on everyone who is not indifferent to the fate and life of the older generation to provide us with all possible support. It is in your power to brighten up the days of the oldest generation.

item.title: Help war veterans
item.description:
Providing veterans of the Great Patriotic War with a dignified old age is one of our most important tasks. The Veteran Organization of the Jewish Community of Estonia unites more than 90 people: they are veterans of the Great Patriotic War, veterans of military service, siege of Leningrad, former ghetto prisoners, workers of the military rear, widows of veterans. Without the tremendous heroic contribution of these people, many of us would not be alive today. Every year we try to attract new funds for projects related to the support of our beloved grandparents who have gone through the horrors of World War II. Our community calls on all caring people to make their contribution to supporting the elderly.

item.title: Victims of ghettos
item.description:
For 20 years our veteran association has been taking care of its comrades, providing them with legal, moral and financial assistance. Many members of the Jewish community in Estonia went through the horrors of war, life in ghettos, concentration camps and survived. With their lives, they prove that the human spirit is strong. They live to pass this memory on to us, their descendants. This memory is hard, therefore, it is best to stick together. In cooperation with the Jewish Community of Estonia, the Association of Former Concentration Camp and Ghetto Prisoners strives to make the lives of their comrades brighter and richer. Today you can also support former prisoners of Nazism.
